title: Quarto Basics
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 4 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Daily ML Log — 2025-11-12
text:
Key formulas
For binary labels \(y \in \{0,1\}\) and logit \(z = w^\top x\):
\[
p(y=1 \mid x) = \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}}.
\]
The per-example loss:
\[
\ell(w) = - \big[ y \log \sigma(z) + (1-y) \log (1-\sigma(z)) \big].
\]
Gradient w.r.t. \(w\):
\[
\nabla_w \ell(w) = (\sigma(z) - y) x.
\]

title: Daily ML Log — 2025-11-12
text:
Quick sanity check in code

import numpy as np

def sigmoid(z):
    return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-z))

rng = np.random.default_rng(0)
X = rng.normal(size=(5, 3))
w = rng.normal(size=3)
y = (rng.random(5) < 0.4).astype(float)

z = X @ w
grad = ((sigmoid(z) - y)[:, None] * X).mean(axis=0)
grad
